resources.string:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Donec a diam lectus. Sed sit amet ipsum mauris. Maecenas congue ligula ac quam viverra nec consectetur ante hendrerit. Donec et mollis dolor. Praesent et diam eget libero egestas mattis sit amet vitae augue. Nam tincidunt congue enim, ut porta lorem lacinia consectetur.
 
Donec ut libero sed arcu vehicula ultricies a non tortor. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aenean ut gravida lorem. Ut turpis felis, pulvinar a semper sed, adipiscing id dolor. Pellentesque auctor nisi id magna consequat sagittis. Curabitur dapibus enim sit amet elit pharetra tincidunt feugiat nisl imperdiet.
 
Ut convallis libero in urna ultrices accumsan. Donec sed odio eros. Donec viverra mi quis quam pulvinar at malesuada arcu rhoncus. Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. In rutrum accumsan ultricies. Mauris vitae nisi at sem facilisis semper ac in est.

iGEM is the biggest international competition of Synthetic Biology, and aims to connect education and competition to advance research in this area. Organised by the MIT since 2004, students from the whole world compete by creating innovative projects in the field of Synthetic Biology.\n \nAt the beginning of summer, the teams receive a kit of biologic parts and work in the laboratory to design synthetic genetical circuits that must function in living cells. Collaboration and exchange between teams is highly valued, in this perspective of advancing Synthetic Biology.

Game Development: 
Paul-Louis Nech 
 
 
Application layouts: 
Paul-Louis Nech 
Goulwen Mintec 
Lionel Chesnais 
 
 
Graphical design: 
Lionel Chesnais 
Marine Mohmmed 
Cyrielle Viaut 
Pascal Charleton 
 
 
Texts and concepts: 
Johanna Chesnel 
Hugo Cremaschi 
Matthieu Da Costa 
Gilles Defrel 
Armelle Louisy 
Marine Mohmmed 
Paul-Louis Nech 
Pauline Trébullen 
Marwa Zerhouni 
 
 
Music and sounds: 
Scott Gratton - Electro Lab 
plasterbrain - Coin GET! 
kantouth - CARTOON-BING-LOW 
 
Many thanks to the help provided by our instructor Samuel Juilliot 
and by our advisors Guillaume Mercy and Pierre Parutto 
 
 
 
Special thanks to our KickStarter backers, and particularly to: 
 
Bendali-amor Samia 
Chesnel Anthony et Véronique 
Cornille Catherine 
Cornille Pierre-Jean 
Cremaschi Laurent 
Da Costa José 
Digan William 
Janny Sirwan 
Louisy Patrick 
Louisy Valérie 
Sophie Poignon
Games build with the AndEngine Game Engine \n
Better interface interaction thanks to the ButterKnife library \n
Sponsors and Team pages build with ludovicroland\'s Android Carousel library, based on Igor Kushnarev\'s work \n
Icons on contact page come from Dan Leech\'s SimpleIcons \n

=== SimpleIcons === 
 
Free Art License 1.3 (FAL 1.3) 
 
Preamble 
 
The Free Art License grants the right to freely copy, distribute, and transform creative works without infringing the author’s rights. 
 
The Free Art License recognizes and protects these rights. Their implementation has been reformulated in order to allow everyone to use creations of the human mind in a creative manner, regardless of their types and ways of expression. 
 
While the public’s access to creations of the human mind usually is restricted by the implementation of copyright law, it is favoured by the Free Art License. This license intends to allow the use of a work’s resources; to establish new conditions for creating in order to increase creation opportunities. The Free Art License grants the right to use a work, and acknowledges the right holder’s and the user’s rights and responsibility. 
 
The invention and development of digital technologies, Internet and Free Software have changed creation methods: creations of the human mind can obviously be distributed, exchanged, and transformed. They allow to produce common works to which everyone can contribute to the benefit of all. 
 
The main rationale for this Free Art License is to promote and protect these creations of the human mind according to the principles of copyleft: freedom to use, copy, distribute, transform, and prohibition of exclusive appropriation. 
 
Definitions 
 
« work » either means the initial work, the subsequent works or the common work as defined hereafter: 
 
« common work » means a work composed of the initial work and all subsequent contributions to it (originals and copies). The initial author is the one who, by choosing this license, defines the conditions under which contributions are made. 
 
« Initial work » means the work created by the initiator of the common work (as defined above), the copies of which can be modified by whoever wants to. 
 
« Subsequent works » means the contributions made by authors who participate in the evolution of the common work by exercising the rights to reproduce, distribute, and modify that are granted by the license. 
 
« Originals » (sources or resources of the work) means all copies of either the initial work or any subsequent work mentioning a date and used by their author(s) as references for any subsequent updates, interpretations, copies or reproductions. 
 
« Copy » means any reproduction of an original as defined by this license. 
 
1. OBJECT 
The aim of this license is to define the conditions under which one can use this work freely. 
 
2. SCOPE 
This work is subject to copyright law. Through this license its author specifies the extent to which you can copy, distribute, and modify it. 
 
2.1 FREEDOM TO COPY (OR TO MAKE REPRODUCTIONS) 
You have the right to copy this work for yourself, your friends or any other person, whatever the technique used. 
 
2.2 FREEDOM TO DISTRIBUTE, TO PERFORM IN PUBLIC 
You have the right to distribute copies of this work; whether modified or not, whatever the medium and the place, with or without any charge, provided that you: 
attach this license without any modification to the copies of this work or indicate precisely where the license can be found, 
specify to the recipient the names of the author(s) of the originals, including yours if you have modified the work, 
specify to the recipient where to access the originals (either initial or subsequent). 
The authors of the originals may, if they wish to, give you the right to distribute the originals under the same conditions as the copies. 
 
2.3 FREEDOM TO MODIFY 
You have the right to modify copies of the originals (whether initial or subsequent) provided you comply with the following conditions: 
all conditions in article 2.2 above, if you distribute modified copies; 
indicate that the work has been modified and, if it is possible, what kind of modifications have been made; 
distribute the subsequent work under the same license or any compatible license. 
The author(s) of the original work may give you the right to modify it under the same conditions as the copies. 
 
3. RELATED RIGHTS 
Activities giving rise to author’s rights and related rights shall not challenge the rights granted by this license. 
For example, this is the reason why performances must be subject to the same license or a compatible license. Similarly, integrating the work in a database, a compilation or an anthology shall not prevent anyone from using the work under the same conditions as those defined in this license. 
 
4. INCORPORATION OF THE WORK 
Incorporating this work into a larger work that is not subject to the Free Art License shall not challenge the rights granted by this license. 
If the work can no longer be accessed apart from the larger work in which it is incorporated, then incorporation shall only be allowed under the condition that the larger work is subject either to the Free Art License or a compatible license. 
 
5. COMPATIBILITY 
A license is compatible with the Free Art License provided: 
it gives the right to copy, distribute, and modify copies of the work including for commercial purposes and without any other restrictions than those required by the respect of the other compatibility criteria; 
it ensures proper attribution of the work to its authors and access to previous versions of the work when possible; 
it recognizes the Free Art License as compatible (reciprocity); 
it requires that changes made to the work be subject to the same license or to a license which also meets these compatibility criteria. 
 
6. YOUR INTELLECTUAL RIGHTS 
This license does not aim at denying your author’s rights in your contribution or any related right. By choosing to contribute to the development of this common work, you only agree to grant others the same rights with regard to your contribution as those you were granted by this license. Conferring these rights does not mean you have to give up your intellectual rights. 
 
7. YOUR RESPONSIBILITIES 
The freedom to use the work as defined by the Free Art License (right to copy, distribute, modify) implies that everyone is responsible for their own actions. 
 
8. DURATION OF THE LICENSE 
This license takes effect as of your acceptance of its terms. The act of copying, distributing, or modifying the work constitutes a tacit agreement. This license will remain in effect for as long as the copyright which is attached to the work. If you do not respect the terms of this license, you automatically lose the rights that it confers. 
If the legal status or legislation to which you are subject makes it impossible for you to respect the terms of this license, you may not make use of the rights which it confers. 
 
9. VARIOUS VERSIONS OF THE LICENSE 
This license may undergo periodic modifications to incorporate improvements by its authors (instigators of the « Copyleft Attitudeâ€ movement) by way of new, numbered versions. 
You will always have the choice of accepting the terms contained in the version under which the copy of the work was distributed to you, or alternatively, to use the provisions of one of the subsequent versions. 
 
10. SUB-LICENSING 
Sub-licenses are not authorized by this license. Any person wishing to make use of the rights that it confers will be directly bound to the authors of the common work. 
 
11. LEGAL FRAMEWORK 
This license is written with respect to both French law and the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works.
A biological game to teach and learn

Our Team, IONIS Paris, developed a two part project around scientific popularisation for the iGEM 2015 competition. The first part consists in a Bio-Console, a device connecting the living with the digital. The IONIS Paris bio-console is composed of: 
• a microfluidic chip 
• a microscope 
• a computer 
• a joystick 
 
On the computer screen, the player can visualise a fluorescent bacterium and control its move with the joystick. The bacterium is integrated in the microfluidic chip build beforehand in a maze shape, and is enlarged via the microscope linked to the computer. 
 
The second part of our project is the mobile application BactMan Adventures, offering several games on the concepts of biotechnology and synthetic biology. 
 
Those games aim at familiarising general public with those big concepts. 
Our philosophy: “Understand and learn while having fun”.
A mixed team to get the best of us
They give us a lot to build our project
We want to hear from you
A competition to celebrate science and knowledge
Design and construction of biological systems

Synthetic biology is biological engineering. 
Its aim is the rational design of systems based on the living or inspired by the living, and endowed with functions inexistent in nature. 
This emerging field will push forward our knowledge of the living world and will enable the development of several industrial applications in areas such as the health sector or the environmental field. 
 
However, as with all technologies, synthetic biology raises optimism and enthousiasm, but also worry and wariness.
A good way to work together

The BioBricks are standardised pieces of DNA, developed to permit a faster building of biological systems. \n \nAs they are built on the same model, we can assemble them as a LEGO® game to finally incorporate them in a living cell.
Congratulations, you just won the last game!
The next game is in %s mode!
To unlock the next game, you need to win the previous one!
We will present our project on Sunday 27, at 09:30 AM in the Room 311. \nCome and bring your friends with you!

string-array.name: glossary_titles
string-array.item: ADN
Replication
Nucleotide
Complementarity
Plasmid
Restriction site (digestion)
Ligation
Biobrick
Petri Dish
Electrophoresis
Transcription
Translation
Mutation
Vitamin
Virus
Phage
Antibiotic

string-array.name: glossary_texts
string-array.item:
DNA (DeoxyriboNucleic Acid) is a huge molecule that contains all information necessary for the proper functioning of the body. 
 
Present in all of human body cells, DNA is also present in all other organisms (plants, birds, insects, bacteria). 
 
It is this molecule that makes us all unique individuals with different characteristics.

Replication is the biological process that occurs during cell division. 
 
During this process, DNA will be copied in two identical copies. 
Therefore, two daughter cells each with DNA from a mother cell will be obtained after this process.

A nucleotide is a principal constituent of the DNA. It is itself composed of three elements: 
 
• A nitrogen base 
• A ribose (sugar) 
• A phosphate 
 
There are 4 basic nucleotides constituting the DNA code: A (Adenine), T (Thymine), C (Cytosine) and G (Guanine).

DNA is a double helix strand. 
 
Imagine a railroad where each side (the bases) must be assembled by complementarity! 
 
A and T are assembled together, and C and G together.

A plasmid is a circular DNA present in addition to the chromosomal DNA of the bacterium. \n \nIt can be transmitted from one bacterium to another and confers new properties to the receiving bacteria (resistance to an antibiotic, for example).

It is a specific part of DNA that is recognized by an enzyme, called restriction enzyme, which cuts DNA at this location. 
 
Picture yourself the enzyme as a pair of scissors that can only cut DNA at these sites! This process is called digestion. 
There are several enzymes and therefore multiple sites in a single DNA. 
 
There are 2 different kinds of digestion: 
• Digestion with blunt ends 
 
• Digestion with sticky ends

Ligation occurs after digestion.
It allows you to stick or stick back together two strands of DNA compatible together. 
 
The enzyme that allows ligation is called Ligase.

BioBricks are fragments of standardized DNA, created to engineer simpler construction of biological systems. 
 
Each BioBrick is delimited by universal prefixes and suffixes, they thus begin and end all in the same way. 
As they are designed on the same model, we can assemble them like "LEGO" and then incorporate them into a living cell. 
 
This standards allows iGEM teams around the world to work together as all work with the same standards.

It is a round plastic box, cover by a lid. Petri dishes are used to make micro-organism cultures (bacteria, fungi etc.). \n \nIn order to grow, micro-organisms needs a suitable culture medium that is introduced in such a box.

This method allows the separation of proteins, DNA or RNA according to their molecular weight. 
These DNA / RNA / protein are previously prepared and then deposited in a gel. This gel is then placed in a special liquid and then subjected to an electric current which enables the separation of molecules. 
 
The smaller, the molecule is, the faster it will migrate on the gel.

Transcription operates thanks to a mechanism similar to the process of replication, however it does not concern any DNA! 
 
In fact, transcription involve the replication of specific DNA areas. These zones are surrounded by promoters and terminators. 
Promoters are sequences that play a regulatory role and that fixes the necessary machinery for replication whereas the terminator marks the end of the sequence to be transcribed. 
RNA, the molecule obtained by transcription, is complementary to the DNA and chemically very close to it, except for some details. 
In RNA, we find the same bases as in DNA except for thymine, replaced by uracil (T becomes U)! 
 
Once formed, RNA will undergo some changes during maturation to be ready for his translation into protein.

Translation is the process of converting genetic information into functional proteins. 
Indeed, RNA create from DNA contains all the data needed to create proteins, it only remains to decrypt this information! 
 
A protein called ribosome is responsible for decoding. After being fixed to the RNA strand, the ribosome will read the nucleic acid sequence by creating "words" of three nucleic acids each. 
These words, called codons, will then be recognized and translated into amino acid to form a protein. As a language translator, the ribosome associates the word to its equivalent in protein language. The dictionary used is called genetic code. 
During this process, the amino acid "read" are attached to each other like a pearl necklace. 
 
Once finished reading the amino acid chain is released. 
She then fold up to adopt its structure and function before finally fulfill its role in its orgaism.

A mutation is a modification in the DNA sequence. This modification can occur naturally, by errors during replication for example, or be induced by mutagens or phenomena said. For example, UV damages DNA and induce mutations. 
 
If these changes are essential for the evolution and the diversity, some variations can also have several consequences for the living organism. 
Some are positive and confer a benefit to the organization, such as a better metabolism, while others are harmless or even harmful. Indeed, if a mutation can allow better functioning of a protein, it can also alter its function and make it ineffective. 
 
There are different types of variations: 
 
• Insertions, where one or more nucleotides are added 
• The deletions, in which one or several nucleotides are deleted existing 
• Substitutions, where one or more bases are replaced with other 
 
How these small changes can have such great consequences? 
 
When translating the genetic information is cut into 3-letter words, the codons. 
The translation of this codon is then looked-up in a "dictionary", the genetic code to translate this word into protein language. 
If one of the letters change or if the words are not separated the same way, the translation into a protein will be altered. 
Fortunately, all mutations are far from harmful! The majority of them do not even have direct consequences because of the redundancy of the genetic code: among codons, there are many synonyms, so even if a base changes, the translation may remain correct. 
 
 The mutations also allow genetic diversity: if we do not have all the eyes of the same color, it is due to individuals not having all the same genes and the same mutations!

A vitamin is an organic substance needed in small amounts for the metabolism of a living organism. It can’t be synthesized in sufficient quantities by the organism. 
 
They are therefore considered essential supplements. Vitamins are classified into two groups: water-soluble vitamins (water-soluble) and lipid-soluble vitamins (fat soluble). The essential role of a vitamin is a transfer from one molecule to another, of an electron, an atom or group of atoms to another. 
 
• Inadequate intake or absence of vitamin causes many diseases such as scurvy, rachitis etc. 
• Excessive intake of vitamins can also cause diseases such as hypervitaminosis, very toxic to the body. 
 
Vitamin requirements are difficult to establish because they vary with the age, sex, size and muscular activity. 
They increase during growth or diseases. In women, the need for vitamins increases during pregnancy and lactation.
A virus is a biological entity that requires a host, usually a cell, for whom it uses the metabolism and its constituents to replicate and live.

Phage or Bacteriophage are viruses that infect bacteria. They are usually very specific and often can infect only one species of bacteria. 
 
This specificity is due to their mechanism of penetration into the bacterial cell: the phages recognize specific receptors on the bacterial surface which allow them to attach and inject their genetic material into the bacterium. 
 
Phages are unable to reproduce on their own. They do it by injecting their genetic material into a bacteria which has the enzymes and the ribosomes needed to replicate and translate its genetic information, the viral genome can therefore be translated and replicated to form many copies of the virus. 
These viruses are then released from the bacteria by a host bacterium lysis mechanism, lysis being a membrane disintegrating mechanism of cell killing of the cell.

An antibiotic is a natural or synthetic substance that blocks the growth or destroys bacteria. 
 
They act specifically on bacteria by selectively blocking one step in an essential mechanism for their development and survival. (Synthesis of their wall, DNA, proteins, etc.) 
This blocking occurs when the antibiotic binds to its target (receptor). 
 
This interaction between the antibiotic and its target is very selective and specific bacteria.
